Cap 160_Section_5.title: Requirements for Valid Will
Cap 160_Section_5.description: Legal requirements for creating a valid will in Kenya
Cap 160_Section_5.legal_text: No will shall be valid unless it is in writing and executed in the following manner: (a) it is signed at the foot or end thereof by the testator or by some other person in his presence and by his direction; (b) such signature is made or acknowledged by the testator in the presence of two or more witnesses present at the same time; (c) such witnesses attest and sign the will in the presence of the testator.
practical_implications: Will must be witnessed by two independent witnesses
Witnesses cannot be beneficiaries
Proper execution prevents will contestation
Electronic wills not recognized under current law

Cap 160_Section_32.title: Intestate Succession Rules
Cap 160_Section_32.description: Rules governing distribution of estate when no valid will exists
Cap 160_Section_32.legal_text: Where an intestate was survived by a spouse or spouses and child or children, the personal representative shall distribute the net intestate estate as follows: (a) the spouse, or if there is more than one spouse, all the spouses in equal shares, shall be entitled to the personal and household effects of the deceased absolutely, and a life interest in the whole residue of the net intestate estate; (b) the child or children shall be entitled to the remainder in the residue of the net intestate estate in equal shares.
practical_implications: Spouse gets life interest, children get remainder
Equal sharing among multiple spouses
Personal effects go entirely to spouse(s)
Surviving spouse cannot dispose of capital freely

Cap 470_Section_32a.title: Inheritance Tax Exemption
Cap 470_Section_32a.legal_text: There shall be exempt from tax under this Act... any amount received by way of inheritance from a deceased person's estate, provided that such inheritance does not exceed five million shillings in value.
practical_implications: Inheritances under KES 5M are tax-free
Excess over KES 5M subject to tax
Property transfers to spouse may have different treatment
Business assets may have special provisions

Cap 167_Section_3.title: Appointment of Trustees
Cap 167_Section_3.description: Legal framework for trust creation and trustee appointment
Cap 167_Section_3.legal_text: A trust may be created by any person who is of sound mind and not a minor. The person creating the trust (settlor) may appoint one or more trustees to hold and manage trust property for the benefit of beneficiaries.
practical_implications: Trustees have fiduciary duties to beneficiaries
Trust property is separate from personal assets
Professional trustees may be appointed
Trust deed must clearly define terms and powers

Cap 285_Section_7.title: Registration of Trust Deeds
Cap 285_Section_7.legal_text: Every instrument creating a trust of immovable property shall be registered in the manner prescribed under this Act. Failure to register may affect the enforceability of the trust against third parties.
practical_implications: Trust deeds involving land must be registered
Registration provides legal protection
Stamp duty payable on registration
Public record creates transparency

No. 4 of 2014_Section_6.title: Types of Marriage in Kenya
No. 4 of 2014_Section_6.description: Legal recognition of different marriage types
No. 4 of 2014_Section_6.legal_text: This Act recognizes the following systems of marriage in Kenya: (a) civil marriages; (b) Christian marriages; (c) Hindu marriages; (d) Islamic marriages; (e) customary marriages.
practical_implications: All marriage types have equal legal status
Affects inheritance and property rights
Polygamous marriages recognized under customary law
Registration requirements vary by type

No. 49 of 2013_Section_6.title: Matrimonial Property Rights
No. 49 of 2013_Section_6.description: Rights and interests in matrimonial property
No. 49 of 2013_Section_6.legal_text: Spouses shall have equal rights at the time of marriage, during the marriage and at the dissolution of the marriage to matrimonial property.
practical_implications: Both spouses have equal property rights
Applies regardless of who purchased property
Affects estate planning and will-making
Property acquired before marriage may be excluded

No. 17 of 2015_Section_142.title: Directors' Duties and Powers
No. 17 of 2015_Section_142.description: Legal duties and powers of company directors
No. 17 of 2015_Section_142.legal_text: A director of a company shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of his office honestly, in good faith and in the best interests of the company.
practical_implications: Directors have fiduciary duties to company
Personal liability for breach of duties
Succession planning must consider director obligations
Corporate assets distinct from personal assets
